title: Define Your One-Sentence Business Idea
description: Clarity beats complexity. If you can't explain it in one sentence, your customers won't understand it either.
task: Write one sentence that clearly explains what your business does and for whom.
steps: Complete this template: 'I help [target customer] achieve [desired outcome] by [your solution]'
Test it on 3 people - can they repeat it back to you?
Refine until it's crystal clear
Write it down and keep it visible
successCriteria: You have one clear sentence that anyone can understand and remember.

title: Identify Your First 10 Potential Customers
description: Your business idea means nothing without people who will pay for it.
task: Create a list of 10 specific people who might pay for your solution.
steps: Think about people you know who have the problem you're solving
Use LinkedIn, Facebook, or your contacts to find them
Write down their names and contact information
Note why each person might need your solution
successCriteria: You have a list with 10 names and contact methods.

title: Create a Simple Landing Page
description: You need a digital presence to test interest and collect leads before building anything complex.
task: Build a one-page website that explains your idea and collects email addresses.
steps: Choose a simple tool like Carrd, Unbounce, or even a Google Form
Write a clear headline using your one-sentence pitch
Add 2-3 bullet points explaining the benefits
Include an email signup form with a call-to-action
successCriteria: You have a live URL where people can learn about your idea and sign up.

title: Conduct Your First Customer Interview
description: Talking to real people reveals what you can't learn from research alone.
task: Have a 15-minute conversation with one potential customer about their problems.
steps: Pick one person from your Day 2 list
Ask about their current challenges, not your solution
Listen more than you talk
Take notes on their exact words and pain points
successCriteria: You have notes from one real conversation with a potential customer.

title: Define Your Minimum Viable Product (MVP)
description: Start with the smallest version that solves the core problem.
task: Write down the simplest version of your product that people would pay for.
steps: List all the features you think your product needs
Circle only the 3 most essential ones
Cross out everything else for version 1
Write a one-paragraph description of this minimal version
successCriteria: You have a clear description of your MVP with 3 core features.

title: Set Up Social Media Profiles
description: Establish your brand presence and start building an audience.
task: Create business profiles on 2-3 relevant social media platforms.
steps: Choose platforms where your customers spend time
Use consistent naming and branding across platforms
Write a clear bio that explains what you do
Post your first piece of content introducing yourself

resources.title: Building a Brand on Social Media

successCriteria: You have active profiles on 2-3 platforms with your first post published.

title: Get Your First Customer Feedback
description: Assumptions kill startups. Real feedback saves months of wasted effort and guides you toward what customers actually want.
task: Interview 3 potential customers about your business idea to validate your assumptions and gather real market insights.
steps: List 10 people who might be interested in your product or service
Reach out using this template message to request 15-minute feedback calls
Schedule and conduct the interviews using prepared questions
Document key insights and patterns from each conversation
successCriteria: You have completed 3 customer interviews and documented at least 5 key insights about your target market's needs and pain points.

title: Create Your First Marketing Message
description: Turn your customer insights into compelling copy that resonates.
task: Write a marketing message based on your customer feedback.
steps: Review your customer interview notes
Identify the exact words customers used to describe their problems
Write 3 different versions of your marketing message
Test each version with a friend or potential customer
successCriteria: You have 3 different marketing messages that use your customers' actual language.

title: Build an Email List of 10 People
description: Start collecting interested prospects before you have anything to sell.
task: Get 10 people to sign up for updates about your business.
steps: Share your landing page with friends and family
Post about your project on social media
Ask your customer interviewees if they want updates
Reach out to people in relevant online communities
successCriteria: You have 10 email addresses of people interested in your business.

title: Price Your Product or Service
description: Set a price that reflects value, not just costs.
task: Determine what you'll charge for your MVP.
steps: Research what competitors charge for similar solutions
Calculate the value you provide to customers
Start with a price that feels slightly uncomfortable (good sign)
Write down your pricing with a simple explanation
successCriteria: You have a clear price for your MVP with reasoning behind it.

title: Create Your First Sales Process
description: Map out exactly how you'll turn prospects into paying customers.
task: Write down the steps someone takes to buy from you.
steps: Map the customer journey from awareness to purchase
Identify where prospects might have questions or objections
Create a simple script or template for sales conversations
Practice your pitch with a friend
successCriteria: You have a documented sales process and practiced your pitch.

title: Make Your First Sales Attempt
description: The only way to learn to sell is by actually selling.
task: Try to sell your MVP to one person, even if it's not built yet.
steps: Pick your most promising prospect
Explain the value and ask for the sale
Handle objections with empathy
Document what you learn, whether they buy or not
successCriteria: You attempted to sell to one person and documented the conversation.

title: Get Customer Feedback on Pricing
description: Validate your pricing with real market feedback.
task: Ask 5 potential customers what they think about your price.
steps: Present your solution and price to potential customers
Ask: 'What do you think about this price?'
Listen for reactions: too high, too low, or just right
Adjust your pricing based on feedback patterns
successCriteria: You have pricing feedback from 5 potential customers and adjusted if needed.

title: Refine Your Value Proposition
description: Use everything you've learned to sharpen your core message.
task: Rewrite your value proposition based on customer feedback.
steps: Review all customer conversations and feedback
Identify the most compelling benefits customers mentioned
Rewrite your one-sentence pitch using their language
Test the new version with a fresh set of people
successCriteria: You have a refined value proposition that uses customer language.

title: Set Up Basic Analytics Tracking
description: Start measuring what matters for your business growth.
task: Install Google Analytics and set up basic tracking for your landing page.
steps: Create a Google Analytics account
Install the tracking code on your landing page
Set up goals for email signups
Check that data is flowing correctly
successCriteria: You have Google Analytics installed and tracking your landing page visitors.
